questions.text: Which among the following is a not a non-essential amino acid?
questions.solution:
Arginine is a semi essential amino acid.

Amino acids are divided into essential and non-essential amino acids. Essential amino acids are not produced in the body and need to be taken in food. Non-essential amino acids can be produced from other substrates in the body via metabolic reactions. Previously there was debate about number of non-essential and number of essential amino acids. The latest edition of Harper’s biochemistry says the following

Non-essential amino acids are:

  • Alanine
  • Asparagine
  • Aspartate
  • Cysteine
  • Glutamate
  • Glutamine
  • Glycine
  • Hydroxyproline
  • Hydroxylysine
  • Proline
  • Serine
  • Tyrosine

Essential amino acids are:

  • Arginine
  • Histidine
  • Isoleucine
  • Leucine
  • Lysine
  • Methionine
  • Phenylalanine
  • Threonine
  • Tryptophan
  • Valine

Arginine is nutritionally “semiessential.” Synthesized at rates inadequate to support growth of children.

questions.text: Millon’s reaction involves detection of which of the following aminoacids
questions.solution:
Millon’s reaction involves detection of Tyrosine. The Millon test was used in many early studies and can detect large amounts of tyrosine and its 4-hydroxy derivatives (i.e., tyrosyluria). Now, Plasma tyrosine levels are usually quantitated by ion-exchange amino acid chromatography. For neonatal screening, spectrophotometric or bacteriologic (Guthrie) assays can be used. 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate and its derivatives can be analyzed by gas chromatography–mass spectrometry.

questions.solution:
The Structure of proline is given below. The ring marked in blue is the Pyrrolidine group. It is also interesting to note that proline is the only aminoacid in the amino (NH2) group is not free but a part of a ring. This is also called imino acid.

questions.text: All of the following are involved in reactions involving Glutamate dehydrogenase except
questions.solution:
Glutamate dehydrogenase catalyzes rapid oxidative deamination of glutamate. Glutamate dehydrogenase, a mitochondrial enzyme, is unusual in that it can use either nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) or its phosphorylated reduced form (NADPH) as a coenzyme.

It is a reversible reaction. The direction of the reaction depends on the relative concentrations of glutamate, α-ketoglutarate, and ammonia and the ratio of oxidized to reduced coenzymes.

questions.text: Cadaverin is derived from
questions.solution:
Cadaverin is derived from lysine. Unusually large quantities of cadaverine and putrescine are excreted in patients with cystinuria. These compounds are generated from arginine, ornithine, and lysine (COAL amino acids) by decarboxylases that are present in colonic flora but that are not present in human tissues.

questions.text: The amino acid deficient in carcinoid syndrome has which of the following groups?
questions.solution:
The amino acid deficient in carcinoid syndrome is tryptophan. It has an indole group.

Carcinoid tumours are neuroendocrine tumours producing serotonin. Serotonin is synthesized in the body from tryptophan. Carcinoid patients can have tryptophan deficiency as the normal intake of niacin and tryptophan don’t meet the demand from the cancer cells. Tryptophan has an indole group.

Tryptophan deficiency results in pellagra.

questions.text: Phenylketonuria can be diagnosed with
questions.solution: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to Phenylketonuria. The first screening test for an inborn error of metabolism was the Guthrie bacterial inhibition test. If the concentration of phenylalanine is more than that usually found in blood, the bacteria will form visible colonies on the agar, indicating a positive test. The ferric chloride test is a urine spot test for phenylketonuria (PKU) and tyrosinemia. Tandem mass spectroscopy can be used to screen blood samples from newborns for the presence and concentrations of amino acids, fatty acids, and other metabolites. Abnormalities in metabolite levels can serve as diagnostic indicators for a variety of genetic disorders, such as phenylketonuria.

questions.text: Cystathionine synthetase deficiency leads to
questions.solution:
Cystathionine synthetase deficiency leads to Homocystinuria type I

Homocystinuria type-1:

  • It is the most common inborn error of methionine metabolism.
  • It is characterized by developmental delay, ectopia lentis, progressive mental retardation, skeleton abnormalities.

Note : 

Homocystinuria type Defect
Type 1 cystathionine ß synthase
Type 2 defect in methylcobalamin formation
Type 3 methyltetrahydrofolate reductase

questions.text: FIGLU (Formiminoglutamic acid) excretion test is used in the assessment of the deficiency of which of the following vitamins?
questions.solution:
FIGLU excretion test is used in the assessment of deficiency of Vitamin B9 (Folic acid).

FIGLU is converted to L-glutamate by the enzyme glutamate formimino transferase. This enzyme uses folate (vitamin B9). In Vitamin B9 deficiency, FIGLU accumulates in the body and is excreted in the urine.

Folic acid is a water-soluble vitamin, and its active form is tetrahydrofolate (THFA). It acts as a carrier of one-carbon groups. These one-carbon groups are attached either to the 5th, 10th, or both 5th and 10th nitrogen atoms of THFA.

The methyl group in N5-methyl THFA is used for the synthesis of active methionine. This takes part in transmethylation reactions required for the synthesis of choline, epinephrine, creatine, etc.

Folate deficiency results in

  • Reduced synthesis of DNA
  • Macrocytic anemia
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia
  • Neural tube defects in the fetus like spina bifida

questions.text: Which of the following is not a FAD requiring enzyme
questions.solution:
Malate dehydrogenase is a NAD requiring enzyme. All other options require FAD.

Important FAD requiring enzymes are

  • Acyl CoA dehydrogenase
  • Succinate dehydrogenase
  • Mitochondrial glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase

Important NAD requiring enzymes are

  • Malate dehydrogenase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex
  • Glyceraldehyde 3-Phosphate dehydrogenase

questions.text: A plasma protein has a large number of tryptophan, valine, histidine and aspartic acid aminoacids. Which of the following is true regarding the orientation of these aminoacids in the 3-dimensional structure of this protein?

choices.text: Most of the tryptophan and aspartic acid aminoacids will be located towards the inside
Most of the valine and histidine aminoacids will be located towards the inside
Most of the tryptophan and valine aminoacids will be located towards the inside
Most of the histidine and aspartic acid aminoacids will be located towards the inside

questions.solution:
Tryptophan and valine are located towards the inside of the plasma protein. 

This is because they are hydrophobic/non-polar while the plasma is mostly made up of water, which is polar.

Amino acids which are polar/hydrophilic face towards the outside of plasma proteins.

Note: Non-polar amino acids face the exterior of a protein when it needs to dissolve in a lipid-rich fluid like the plasma membrane.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought with a history of impaired vision. On examination, she has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue iris. The child has a normal IQ.  You suspect a disorder due to a deficiency of an enzyme tyrosinase. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase point to the diagnosis of albinism.

The first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L-tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme tyrosinase. Tyrosinase again acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin. Mutations in the tyrosinase gene lead to a complete inability to produce melanin.

Albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. This manifests as white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-gray in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. The IQ of the child will be normal.

Given below is an image of a young child with albinism showing white hair, skin, and pale iris:

Other options:

Option B: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to phenylketonuria. This defect results in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Infants appear normal at birth. They gradually develop hyperactivity, agitation, low IQ, and hypopigmentation (due to tyrosine deficiency), Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odor in the body sweat, and urine.

Option C: The metabolic defect in alkaptonuria is a defective homogentisate oxidase. Patients typically will have dark urine or urine that turns dark on standing, ochronosis(bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue), arthritis, the pigment in the sclera, and ear cartilage.

Option D: Tyrosinemia type 2 (oculocutaneous type) is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical findings include palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia, and learning disability.

questions.text: In a patient with scurvy, which of the following is deficient
questions.solution:
Scurvy is dietary deficiency of vitamin C, it is associated with an impaired ability of connective tissue to form hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine. Vitamin C is a cofactor required for the synthesis of hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine which is an important step in the post translational modification of collagen during its biosynthesis.

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids has an ammonia group in its side chain and is thus likely to be an intermediate of the urea cycle?
questions.solution:
• Arginine is an amino acid having an ammonia side chain and is also part of the urea cycle.
  • Citrulline and ornithine are other important urea cycle intermediates.
  • Aspartate is condensed with citrulline to form argininosuccinate in the urea cycle(Aspartate is not an intermediate)
  • Acetylglutamate is a cofactor in the joining of carbon dioxide with ammonia to form carbamoyl phosphate at the beginning of the urea cycle.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A noncompetitive inhibitor of an enzyme does which of the following?
questions.solution:
In contrast to competitive inhibitors, Consequently, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. For this reason, the degree of inhibition is based solely upon the concentration of inhibitor, and increasing the substrate concentrations does not compete with or change the inhibition. Therefore, unlike the increase in Km seen with competitive inhibition, in noncompetitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km usually remains the same. While competitive inhibitors can be overcome at a sufficiently high concentration of substrate, noncompetitive inhibition is irreversible

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: Oxidative phosphorylation couples generation of ATP with which of the following first?
questions.solution: Proton translocation across the mitochondrial membrane generates an electrochemical potential difference composed of a pH gradient and an electrical potential. This electrochemical potential difference is used to drive ATP synthase to form ATP. During this process NADH and water are oxidized, not reduced, by coupling with oxygen as the ultimate electron donor.

questions.text: Which one of the following tissues can metabolize glucose, fatty acids, and ketone bodies for ATP production?
questions.solution: Muscle cells are the only cells listed that are capable of utilizing all the energy sources available—glucose, fatty acids, and, during fasting, ketone bodies. Mitochondria are required for metabolism of fatty acids and ketone bodies. Since red blood cells (erythrocytes) do not contain mitochondria, no utilization of these energy sources is possible. Although the brain may utilize glucose and ketone bodies, fatty acids cannot cross the blood-brain barrier. Hepatocytes (liver cells) are the sites of ketone body production, but the mitochondrial enzyme necessary for utilization of ketone bodies is not present in hepatocytes.

questions.text: Primary products of pentose phosphate pathway are
questions.solution: The pentose phosphate cycle does not produce ATP, but instead produces ribose and NADPH. NADP+ is the hydrogen acceptor instead of NAD +, as in glycolysis. In the oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway, NADPH is generated by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase. NADPH is also generated by 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase. Ribose is generated in the nonoxidative phase.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds should be a component of TPN?
questions.solution: Linoleate and a-linolenate are the essential fatty acids required in the human diet, hence they need to be present in TPN. Palmitate (C16:0) is synthesized by the fatty acid synthase complex. Phosphatidic acid is an intermediate in triacylglycerol synthesis, which is formed using glycerol as a precursor in the liver and using glucose as a precursor in adipose tissue. It can be synthesized without the need for an essential fatty acid.

questions.text: The major carriers of triacylglycerols are which of the following?
questions.solution: The major carriers of triacylglycerols are chylomicrons (synthesized in the intestine from dietary fat) and VLDL (synthesized in the liver). The triacylglycerols are digested in capillaries by lipoprotein lipase. The fatty acids that are produced are used for energy by cells or are converted back to triacylglycerols and stored. IDL and LDL are digestion products of VLDL, which have reduced amounts of triglyceride compared with VLDL. HDL has the least amount of triglyceride of any lipoprotein particle.

questions.text: LCAT is involved in which of the following processes?

choices.text: The transfer of cholesterol esters from HDL to other lipoproteins
Endocytosis of HDL particles into hepatocytes

questions.solution:
LCAT converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters, which accumulate in the core of HDL. This is an important part of reverse cholesterol transport. These cholesterol esters are transferred from HDL to VLDL and LDL (via the cholesterol ester transfer protein reaction), which are then taken up by receptors in the liver. Therefore, LCAT is important for removing cholesterol from peripheral cells by inducing esterification of cholesterol, thus allowing eventual cholesterol uptake by the liver. LCAT is not involved in endocytosis of HDL into hepatocytes, in the transfer of cholesterol esters from HDL to other lipoproteins, or in hydrolysis of HDL.

Note:

ACAT - converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters in the liver and intestines (intracellular). ACAT uses Acyl-CoA.

LCAT - converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters in the intravascular compartment (lipoprotein) in the peripheral tissues. LCAT uses phosphatidylcholine.

apo A-I - is the activator of LCAT.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes patients with type II familial hypercholesterolemia?

choices.text: After LDL binds to the LDL receptor, the LDL is degraded extracellularly
The number of LDL receptors on the surface of hepatocytes increases
Excessive cholesterol is released by LDL

questions.solution:
Cholesterol synthesis by hepatocytes is increased in patients with type II hyperlipoproteinemia or familial hypercholesterolemia.

Normally, LDL binds to the LDL receptor, and this complex is internalized. The LDL is degraded intracellularly, and the cholesterol released from the LDL migrates to the cytosol. The increase in intracellular cholesterol inhibits HMG-CoA reductase, resulting in decreased cholesterol synthesis by hepatocytes.

Familial hypercholesterolemia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to mutations that reduce the functioning of LDL receptors (option B), the most common being a mutation in the LDLR gene itself. The endocytosis of the receptor with bound LDL is prevented. The resulting variation in the intracellular cholesterol levels affects the inhibition of HMG-CoA reductase. Since HMG-CoA reductase is not properly inhibited, cholesterol synthesis by hepatocytes increases in these patients. Thus, an extremely high serum cholesterol level results from increased cellular synthesis and release of VLDL (Option D), and high levels of LDL particles in circulation (not degraded externally as in Option A).

Physical findings present in some of the patients include tendon xanthomas (especially involving the Achilles tendons) and corneal arcus. These patients may have a myocardial infarction at a young age. Diagnosis is usually established based on biochemical tests. LDL cholesterol >190 mg/dL or total serum cholesterol >400 mg/dL without any secondary etiology should point to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes catalyze the Activation or deactivation of specific amino acid residues by phosphorylation
questions.solution:
Protein kinases cause activation or deactivation of certain key regulatory proteins by covalent modification of specific serine, threonine, or tyrosine hydroxyl residues by phosphorylation. The phosphorylation reaction itself is catalyzed by phosphorylase kinase. Protein phosphatases can quickly reverse such effects, by dephosphorylating these activating enzymes. Activated muscle glycogen phosphorylase a is deactivated by a specific phosphatase that hydrolyzes the phosphoryl group of serine 14. Whether the phosphorylated or dephosphorylated form of a protein predominates depends on the relative activities of the kinase versus the phosphatase.

Kinases - Phosphorylate

Phosphatases - Dephosphorylate

questions.text: Which of the following has the strongest tendency to gain electrons?
questions.solution:
Oxygen is the terminal acceptor of electrons in the electron transport chain (ETC).  Electron transport chain as the name indicates, is a series of electron transfer steps, the electrons move from one complex to the next in the cycle.

Electrons flow down the ETC to oxygen because it has the highest (most positive) reduction potential (E0). The other choices precede oxygen in the ETC and have lower E0 values.

questions.text: Which of the following regulates lipolysis in adipocytes?

choices.text: Activation of fatty acid synthesis mediated by cyclic AMP
Activation of triglyceride lipase as a result of hormone-stimulated increases in cyclic AMP levels
Glycerol phosphorylation to prevent futile esterification of fatty acids
Activation of cyclic AMP production by insulin

questions.solution:
Lipolysis is directly regulated by hormones in adipocytes. Epinephrine stimulates adenylate cyclase to produce cyclic AMP, which in turn stimulates a protein kinase. The kinase activates triglyceride lipase by phosphorylating it.

Lipolysis then proceeds and results in the release of free fatty acids and glycerol. A futile re-esterification of free fatty acids is prevented since adipocytes contain little glycerol kinase to phosphorylate the liberated glycerol (incorrect answer c), which must be processed in the liver.

Inhibition of lipolysis occurs in the presence of insulin, which lowers cyclic AMP levels (incorrect answer d).

Fatty acid synthesis is the opposite of fatty acid breakdown/lipolysis (incorrect answer a).

questions.text: Which of the following apoproteins is an activator of lipoprotein lipase?
questions.solution:
Apo C-II is an activator of lipoprotein lipase. 

Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyses the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy.

Apolipoproteins or apoproteins are the protein moiety of lipoproteins. Usually one or more of these are present in each lipoprotein. They are denoted as apo followed by the letters A, B, C, etc. The various functions of apolipoproteins include: 

  • They are part of the structure of lipoproteins
  • They can act as enzyme co-factors, for example, apo A-I for lecithin: cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT), apo C-II for lipoprotein lipase
  • They act as ligands for interaction with lipoprotein receptors in tissues, for example, apo B100 for LDL receptors

Other options: 

Option A: Apo A is the major apolipoprotein of HDL (high-density lipoprotein).

Option B: Apo B100 is the major apolipoprotein of LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and VLDL (very low-density lipoprotein). Apo B48 is the major apolipoprotein of chylomicrons.

Option D: Apo E is transferred by HDL to nascent chylomicrons and nascent VLDL to form mature forms of those particles.

Related Pearl: Distribution of Various Apolipoproteins on Lipoproteins

questions.text: Arsenite inhibits which of the following steps of the TCA cycle

choices.text: Conversion of α-ketoglutarate to Succinyl CoA
Conversion of Succinyl CoA to Succinate

questions.solution:
Arsenite inhibits conversion of α-ketoglutarate to Succinyl CoA by non-competitively inhibiting α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: All of the following are cofactors for enzymes in the TCA cycle except
questions.solution:
Folate is not involved in the TCA cycle

  • Option A: Niacin

Active form: NAD+

Cofactor for: Isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase and Malate dehydrogenase complex

  • Option B: Mn2+

Cofactor for Isocitrate dehydrogenase

  • Option C: Riboflavin

Active form: FAD

Cofactor for: Succinate dehydrogenase

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ATP synthase is false

choices.text: It is located in the inner mitochondrial membrane
It requires a proton motive force to form ATP in the presence of ADP and Pi
ATP is produced when part of the molecule rotates
One ATP molecule is formed for each full revolution of the molecule

questions.solution:
Three ATP molecules are generated for each full revolution of the molecule not one ATP.

ATP synthase is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane, together with the respiratory chain complexes. The proton motive force drives a membrane-located ATP synthase that forms ATP in the presence of Pi + ADP. ATP is produced when part of the molecule rotates. Several subunits of the protein form a ball-like shape arranged around an axis known as F1. The flow of protons through F0 cause it to rotate, driving the production of ATP.

Note that there are 3 α and 3 β subunits. The β subunits take up ADP and Pi to form ATP. Since there are 3 β subunits, 3ATP molecules are formed for each revolution.

questions.text: The availability of which of the following substance is rate-limiting in the clearance of ethanol?
questions.solution: Ethanol is cleared from the body by oxidation catalyzed by two NAD+ linked enzymes: alcohol dehydrogenase and acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. These enzymes act mainly in the liver to convert alcohol to acetaldehyde and acetate, respectively. The NADH level is significantly increased in the liver during oxidation of alcohol, owing to the consumption of NAD+ This leads to a swamping of the normal means of regenerating NAD+. Thus, NAD + becomes the rate-limiting factor in oxidation of excess alcohol.

questions.text: All of the following are allosteric inhibitors of pyruvate dehydrogenase except
questions.solution:
Allosteric inhibitor is defined as a substance that binds to the enzyme and induces the enzyme's inactive form. Allosteric regulators are an important feedback inhibition mechanism, where the end products of the reaction inhibit the reaction producing them.

Allosteric inhibitors of pyruvate dehydrogenase are:

  • NADH
  • Acetyl CoA
  • ATP

questions.text: 5s rRNA is synthesized mainly by which of the following?
questions.solution:
5s rRNA is synthesized by RNA Polymerase III.

Related Pearl: RNA polymerase in Humans and Their Major Products

Types

Major Products

RNA polymerase I

rRNA

RNA polymerase II

mRNA, miRNA, snRNA, lncRNA

RNA polymerase III

tRNA, 5srRNA

questions.text: Rifampin inhibits which one of the following types of enzymes?
questions.solution:
Rifampin works by inhibiting the beta subunit of the bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RNA polymerase).

Option A: A DNA-dependent DNA polymerase, such as bacterial Pol III, directs DNA replication, whereas bacterial Pol I is involved with DNA repair and lagging strand DNA synthesis.

Option C: An example of a RNA-dependent DNA polymerase is reverse transcriptase, found in retroviruses.

Option D: Only certain RNA viruses, such as poliovirus, code for RNA-dependent RNA polymerases.

questions.text: A mutation to this sequence in eukaryotic messenger RNA (RNA) will affect the process by which the 3'-end poly-A tail is added to the mRNA
questions.solution:
• AAUAAA is present at the 3’ end, it is the polyadenylation sequence.
  • Eukaryotic messenger RNA usually undergoes post transcriptional modification, polyadenylation is an important part of this post transcriptional modification.
  • An endonuclease cleaves messenger RNA just downstream of this polyadenylation signal, creating a new 3'-end to which the poly A polymerase adds the poly-A tail using ATP as the substrate in a template-independent process.
  • These tails help stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation. After the mRNA enters the cytosol, the poly-A tail is gradually shortened.
  • CAAT and TATAAA are sequences found in promoters for RNA polymerase II. 
  • CCA is added to the 3'-end of transfer RNA(tRNA) by nucleotidyltransferase.

questions.text: You are a junior researcher studying about the properties of apoproteins.  Which of the following is the basis for the intestine-specific expression of apolipoprotein B-48?
questions.solution:
The basis for the intestine-specific expression of apolipoprotein B-48 is RNA editing.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is a result of RNA editing. The ApoB gene is transcribed into an mRNA that leads to the synthesis of 100 kDa protein in the liver, which is called apoB100. In the intestine, the same primary transcript is formed, but a cytidine deaminase converts a CAA codon in the mRNA into a UAA codon; thus codon for glutamine is changed to a termination codon. Thus 48kDa protein has resulted; this is apoB48.

DNA rearrangement, transposition and alternate splicing, do alter gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

Related Pearl: Distribution of Various Apolipoproteins on Lipoproteins

Lipoprotein

Apolipoprotein

Chylomicrons

A-I, A-II, A-IV, B-48, C-I, C-II, C-III, E

Chylomicrons remnants

B-48, E

VLDL

B-100, C-I, C-II, C-III, E

IDL

B-100, E

LDL

B-100

HDL

A-I, A-II, A-IV, C-I, C-II, C-III, D, E

Pre- β- HDL

A-I

 

Related Pearl: Lipoprotein: Types, Sources and Action

Lipoproteins

Source

Action

Chylomicrons

Derived from intestinal absorption of triacylglycerol and other lipids

Carry exogenous/dietary triacylglycerol from the intestine to peripheral organs

Very low density lipoproteins (VLDL)

Derived from the liver

Carry endogenous triacylglycerol from the liver to peripheral organs

Low-density lipoproteins (LDL)

Derived from VLDL

Involved in cholesterol transport

Highdensity lipoproteins (HDL)

Derived from Liver, intestine, VLDL, chylomicrons

Involved in reverse cholesterol & Phospholipids transport and also in VLDL and chylomicron metabolism

Intermediate density lipoproteins(IDL)

VLDL

Triacylglycerol & cholesterol transport

questions.text: Pseudouridine and ribothymidine are present as nucleotides in _____.
questions.solution:
Pseudouridine and ribothymidine are present as nucleotides in transfer RNAs (tRNAs).

Transfer RNA is a type of RNA that helps to transport amino acids from the cell cytoplasm to the ribosome, where protein synthesis is taking place. Since they are soluble in nature, they are also known as soluble RNA (sRNA). They undergo internal base-pairing (represented by the black dotted lines in the image below) to form the secondary cloverleaf structure.

Each part of the cloverleaf structure serves a different purpose. The parts of the cloverleaf include:

  • Anticodon loop
  • Acceptor arm
  • D loop
  • The ribothymidine pseudouridine cytidine (TΨC) loop
  • Variable loop

The image given below shows the cloverleaf structure of tRNA.

The anticodon loop shown is where the anticodon triplet codons are present that make a tRNA specific. This anticodon will base pair with the complementary codon on the mRNA (messenger RNA) strand undergoing translation.

The acceptor arm is at the 3' end. This 3' end of the tRNA has the CCA sequence. The hydroxyl group on the A of the CCA sequence gets charged by accepting the amino acid specific to the codon (on the mRNA) that pairs with the anticodon loop. This then gets added to the elongating polypeptide chain. 

The D loop, TΨC loop, and variable loop are involved in defining the specific tRNA and ensuring accurate codon-anticodon base pairing.

Thus, a specific tRNA exists for each of the 20 amino acids that are commonly present in proteins. This tRNA acts as a mediator between the cytosolic amino acids and the mRNA strand undergoing translation.

Other options:

Option B: rRNAs (ribosomal RNA) are found within ribosomes and do not contain these modified bases.

Option C: hnRNA (heterogenous nuclear RNA) is processed to produce mRNA, which also lacks these modified bases.

Option D: snRNPs (small nuclear RNAs complexed with protein) are involved in splicing and also lack ribothymidine and pseudouridine.

Related Pearl: Types of RNA

Protein coding RNA

Non Protein coding RNA

mRNA

Ribosomal RNAs (rRNA)

Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs)

Transfer RNAs (tRNA)

Small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs)

Micro and silencing RNAs (miRNAs and siRNAs)

Related Pearl: RNA polymerase in Humans and Their Major Products

Types

Major Products

RNA polymerase I

rRNA

RNA polymerase II

mRNA, miRNA, snRNA, lncRNA

RNA polymerase III

tRNA, 5srRNA

questions.text: All of the following enzymes participate in reversible non-oxidative phase of the HMP except
questions.solution:
HMP pathway has a series of reactions which are divided into two phases

  • Irreversible oxidative phase
  • Reversible nonoxidative phase

In the first phase (Irreversible oxidative phase), glucose6-phosphate undergoes dehydrogenation and decarboxylation to yield a pentose, ribulose-5-phosphate. 

In the second phase, ribulose-5-phosphate is converted back to glucose-6-phosphate by a series of reactions involving mainly two enzymes: transketolase and transaldolase

Related Pearl: Phases of HMP Shunt and the Enzymes Involved

Phases

Enzymes

Irreversible oxidative phase

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

6-Phosphogluconate dehydrogenase

Reversible non-oxidative phase

 

3-Epimerase or Keto-isomerase

Transketolase

Transaldolase

Phosphohexose isomerase

questions.text: Which of the following converts glucose to sorbitol?
questions.solution:
• Glucose enters tissues such as nerves, kidney, and the lens of the eye by an insulin-independent mechanism. In these tissues, glucose is reduced to sorbitol by aldose reductase. The damage to these tissues is believed to be due to an osmotic effect because the sorbitol is unable to escape these tissues readily.
  • Sorbitol dehydrogenase converts sorbitol to fructose.
  • Hexokinase phosphorylates glucose to glucose 6-phosphate.

questions.text: In contracting skeletal muscle, a sudden elevation of the sarcoplasmic calcium concentration will result in:

choices.text: Activation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-dependent protein kinase A
Conversion of cAMP to AMP by phosphodiesterase
Direct activation of glycogen synthase b
Direct activation of phosphorylase kinase b

questions.solution: Ca 2+ released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum during exercise binds to the calmodulin subunit of phosphorylase kinase, there by allosterically activating the “b” form of this enzyme. The other choices are not caused by an elevation of cytosolic calcium.

questions.text: A processed urine sample of a patient shows the following type of absorption of spectrophotometry. The patient has a disorder involving metabolism of
questions.solution: The graph shows peak absorption at 400 nm, it is highly suggestive of porphyrins. The band of 400nm is also called soret band. The conjugated double bonds in the pyrrole rings and linking methylene groups of porphyrins (absent in the porphyrinogens) are responsible for their characteristic absorption and fluorescence spectra.

questions.text: Decreased activity of which of the following enzymes would confirm the suspected diagnosis of Hurler syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Hurler syndrome, a defect in the lysosomal degradation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs ) with corneal clouding, is due to a deficiency in α-L-iduronidase.
  • Beta-glucuronidase is deficient in Sly syndrome, and iduronatesulfatase is deficient in Hunter syndrome.
  • Glycosyltransferases are enzymes of GAG synthesis.

questions.text: After 30 hours of fasting, which of the following is most important for the maintenance of normal blood glucose levels?
questions.solution: About 2 to 3 hours after a meal, the liver maintains normal blood glucose by glycogenolysis. Within 30 hours, liver glycogen stores are depleted, leaving gluconeogenesis as the primary process for maintaining normal blood glucose. Ketone bodies are generated, triacylglycerols are broken down, and muscle protein breakdown increases. In the fed state, insulin increases; in the fasting state, glucagon increases, while insulin decreases.

questions.text: CO2 is released in which of the following steps of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle?
questions.solution:
CO2 is released in steps B and C. Step B is the conversion of isocitrate to ketoglutarate which is catalyzed by isocitrate dehydrogenase. Step C is the conversion of ketoglutarate to succinate which is catalyzed by alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. In these steps, there are releases of CO2 and conversion of NAD+ to NADH.

The tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA, Kreb's cycle, or citric acid cycle) refers to a sequence of reactions that take place in the mitochondria. It oxidizes acetyl-CoA to CO2 and reduces coenzymes that are reoxidized through the electron transport chain, with the formation of ATP. It is an aerobic pathway.

The TCA cycle is the final common pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins. Most amino acids get metabolized either to acetyl CoA or to an intermediate of the cycle. It plays an important role in gluconeogenesis, lipogenesis, and the interconversion of amino acids. Since it functions in both oxidative as well as synthetic processes, it is an amphibolic pathway.

3 molecules of NADH and 1 molecule of FADH2 are produced for each molecule of acetyl-CoA that is catabolized during one turn of the TCA cycle. Each NADH gives approximately 2.5 ATP and FADH2 gives 1.5 ATP when they are reoxidized. In addition, 1 ATP (or GTP) is formed at the substrate level when succinyl CoA is converted to succinate. Thus, 10 ATP are generated for one turn of the TCA cycle (3x2.5 ATP from NADH +1.5 ATP from FADH2+1GTP).

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

Related Pearl: Energy production in TCA Cycle

Reaction  Enzyme Method of ATP Generation Net ATP Produced
Isocitrate to alpha keto glutarate Isocitrate dehydrogenase From NADH 1*2.5 ATP per NADH = 2.5 ATP
Alpha keto glutarate to Succinyl CoA α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex From NADH 1*2.5 ATP per NADH = 2.5 ATP
Succinyl Co A to Succinate Succinate thiokinase GTP 1GTP
Succinate to fumarate Succinate dehydrogenase From FADH2 1*1.5 ATP per FADH2 = 1.5 ATP
Malate to Oxaloacetate Malate dehydrogenase From NADH 1*2.5 ATP per NADH = 2.5 ATP
    Total ATP produced per turn of the TCA 10 ATP

questions.text: Which statement best explains the function of eEF-2?

choices.text: It is required for the translocation of peptidyl-tRNA during translation
It is required for the initiation of protein synthesis
It is the agent that binds to, and is inactivated by, chloramphenicol
It functions as a peptidyl transferase

questions.solution:
Eukaryotic elongation factor 2 (eEF-2) is required for the translocation of peptidyl-tRNA along the mRNA during translation.

The elongation reaction requires GTP hydrolysis. The corresponding elongation factor in bacteria is EF-G. Diphtheria toxin ADP-ribosylates eEF-2, leading to its inactivation.

Other options:

Option B: Initiation of eukaryotic protein synthesis requires several initiation factors, designated eIF-1, eIF-2, etc.

Option C: Chloramphenicol inhibits prokaryotic peptidyl transferase.

Option D: Peptidyl transferase is an rRNA (within the large ribosomal subunit) involved in formation of the peptide bond between the amino acid groups within the A and P sites of the ribosome.

questions.text: Creatinine is produced from which of the following precursors?
questions.solution:
• Creatinine is formed from the cyclization of creatine phosphate, which is formed from glycine, arginine, and S-Adenosyl Methionine.
  • Glutamine, aspartic acid, and CO2 are involved in the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines. Glutamine, cysteine, and glycine form the antioxidant molecule glutathione
  • Glycine and succinyl CoA are the precursors to the formation of heme.

questions.text: The complete lack of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity leads to which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Crigler-Najjar syndrome, type I, results from a complete lack of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity.

Hereditary disorders of bilirubin metabolism

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemias

  • Crigler-Najjar syndrome, type I
    • Absent Bilirubin UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity.
    • Appears in the neonatal period and persists for life.
    • Kernicterus is common
    • No response to phenobarbital
  • Crigler-Najjar syndrome, type II
    • Markedly reduced (0–10% of normal) UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity.
    • Detected in infancy or later in life
    • Kernicterus is rare
    • Phenobarbital decreases bilirubin by >25%
  • Gilbert syndrome
    • Reduced (10–33% of normal) UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity
    • Diagnosed in adult life
    • Precipitated by stress, fatigue, alcohol use, inducing agents

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemias

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome
    • Defect in biliary excretion (MRP2 protein)
    • Mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia
    • Normal liver function with dark pigment in liver
    • Characteristic pattern of urinary coproporphyrins
    • Nonvisualization of gallbladder on oral cholecystography
  •  Rotor syndrome
    • Defect in biliary excretion (OATP1B1 and OATP1B3)
    • Mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia
    • Normal liver function without pigmentation
    • Gallbladder is visualized on oral cholecystography

questions.text: After binding intracellular receptors, steroids regulate the rate of which of the following?
questions.solution: Steroid hormones enter cells and bind to receptor proteins. The receptor-hormone complex binds to specific response elements, or the regulatory region of DNA, and activates gene transcription.

questions.text: A patient has porphobilinogen (PBG) deaminase deficiency, which of the following substances is expected to increase?
questions.solution:
Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is a genetic metabolic disorder affecting the production of heme, the oxygen-binding prosthetic group of hemoglobin. It is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase.

Its inheritance is more commonly autosomal dominant;however, autosomal recessive forms of this disorder have occurred.

AIP is caused by mutations in the HMBS gene, which codes for the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase in which insufficient hydroxymethylbilane is produced, leading to a build-up of porphobilinogen in the cytoplasm.

questions.text: Which of the following exerts a positive influence on the activity of PDH?
questions.solution:
Regulation of the PDH complex is effected by both allosteric means and by phosphorylation. Allosteric effectors of the enzyme complex are of both positive and negative type. The complex is phosphorylated by a specific kinase identified as PDH kinase and phosphate is removed by PDH phosphatase. When in the unphosphorylated state the complex is much more active, therefore the activity of PDH phosphatase is important for maintaining the PDH complex in the active state.

Acetyl-CoA (option A) and NADH (option D) are both allosteric inhibitors of the nonphosphorylated form of the PDH complex and also serves to activate PDH kinase leading to phosphorylated and inhibited PDH. Like acetylCoA and NADH, ATP (option B) allosterically activates the PDH kinase leading to phosphorylated and inhbited PDH.

questions.text: Epigenetics  means

choices.text: Gene expression following  point mutations in DNA
Gene expression that is restricted to a specific cell lineage
Genotype differences are not reflected by phenotype differences
Phenotype differences that are independent of genotype variation

questions.solution:
Epigenetics refers to the mechanisms by which levels of gene expression can be exquisitely modulated, not by variations in the primary genetic sequence of DNA but rather by postgenomic alterations in DNA and chromatin structure, which influence how, when, and where genes are expressed.

DNA methylation and methylation and acetylation of histone proteins that interact with nuclear DNA to form chromatin are key mediators of these events.
